title: Creme de la creme!
text: This restaurant is simply superb! The service is impeccable, no detail goes unnoticed, and the food is creative and inspired. We had the 3 course prix fixe for my birthday,and we got an additional chocolate cake for dessert! The tables are well spaced, the dining room is carpeted and quiet, and the room elegant. We enjoyed the white asparagus and the peekytoe crab appetizers followed by chicken stuffed with crab mousseline and accompanied by fresh morels and sautéed spinach. Desserts were equally elaborate and tasty. My spouse had the wine pairings for each course and I enjoyed a lovely Chablis and a Tokaji with my strawberry dessert. A wonderful place!!

title: Classy, clean dinner on Madison!
text: While not as atmospheric as some diners, Three Guys is very clean and very good! They excel at a grilled ham and cheese sandwich with good cole slaw and their tuna melt is also high quality. Lots of booths and attentive wait staff! Perfectly located near Frick Madison.

title: Great for good diner food!
text: My spouse loves their grilled bacon and cheese sandwich with a side of cole slaw and endless cups of American coffee. I like the tuna salad in a pita also. Family-run place, friendly efficient service and always satisfying!

title: Very good food, brisk service!
text: I like the food at Barbaresco a lot. I just wish that the wait staff wouldn’t be quite so eager to take my drink order before I even get my jacket off and get settled! Once we’re seated, the pace is efficient but not quite as hurried. We enjoyed their version of veal saltimbocca and the chicken in a Gorgonzola cream cause are well as the Caesar salad and the caprese one. Reliably very good!

title: Food acceptable, but crowded, noisy and slow service!
text: We dined here on a Sunday night which was probably our first mistake. Seating options were initially inside or on the sidewalk which didn’t appeal so we agreed to the garden. It was downstairs, not a garden or a patio, but an enclosed room with some dividers, but lots of tables, no real air circulation, and very noisy! A bigger mistake. It filled up and we felt somewhat trapped, plus the service was abysmally slow. Our waitress tried somewhat, but also said the kitchen was dealing with a lot of delivery orders. We almost left after our salad arrived, but stuck it out. The sole with lemon caper sauce was quite nice as was their veal Buon Gusto style. Accompanying broccoli was overcooked.

title: Favorite dining spot!
text: Via Carota is only serving in their outdoor enclosure and reservations are very limited and hard to get. Nonetheless, we had an early lunch slot and delighted in two longtime favorites: grilled artichokes and the Meyer lemon risotto. The artichokes are my spouse’s favorite and I consider their risotto food for the gods. It satisfies on so many levels. In addition, we enjoyed the fritto misto, although I thought it was a tad on the dry side and could have been cooked a bit less and/or served with more lemon wedges or some aioli. They are encouraging ordering on your phone, but they will also give you a paper menu. Now we know to use our phones for the next visit!

title: Delicious Turkish food!
text: With a wide variety of choices and a very friendly, helpful waitress, this was a fun place for dinner. We sat outside on the sidewalk, nicely distanced from the other outdoor tables. The hot red pepper and walnut spread was very hot, but my spouse really liked it! Between us, we shared an order of the manti, lovely mini dumplings in yogurt sauce, and the lamb shish kebab plus an additional order of greens. Everything very tasty! We have added this restaurant to our regular list!

title: Always a pleasure for good food!
text: We sat upstairs inside since it was very windy on their porch. An almost full dining room, but good service nonetheless. Our table enjoyed wines by the glass and the salmon with shrimp and spinach, crab cakes, lobster with mac and cheese, and the stuffed chicken. Everything delicious and better than I recalled! Nice sized entree portions and the Caesar salads easily served two!

title: Expanded outdoor seating along with FRESH fish!
text: The food at Swordfish Grill is a cut above that of some other casual local restaurants. We enjoyed the firecracker shrimp, and shared a Caesar salad which gave the two of us each a nice serving. My spouse had the seared tuna and I tucked into the salmon tacos, a special that day. Two flour tortillas with a generous amount of salmon and tasty slaw. Seating options include under an overhang, in the open toward the bay or inside completely protected. Spacing of tables was good and servers were masked. Our server, Brook, was pleasant and attentive in the nicest way1

title: Attractive outdoor patio dining!
text: Their patio is large and the tables well spaced. Four of us enjoyed the Caesar salad, house salad and fried calamari. Entree choices of shrimp on lobster ravioli and meatloaf and especially the featured branzino were all tasty! Paper napkins were very flimsy and inappropriate given the dinner entree prices!

title: Tasty Italian for takeout!
text: We have now done takeout from Pesto several times. Their caprese salad is both delicious and beautifully presented with burrata. We like their veal saltimbocca and have tried the spaghetti and meatballs. The latter is nice with angel hair and small meatballs, but a bit too garlicky for me. Caesar salad also very good!

title: Comfortable outside dining safely distanced!
text:
We like this little restaurant and during Covid-19 have been avoiding restaurants. We were pleased to sit outside on the blocked off street (called patio) and have a server wait on us and serve us. A first after many months!
Our appetizer was excellent and my spouse and I both enjoyed our last lobster rolls of the season with tarragon mayonnaise .
A perfect ending to a Maine sojourn before flying home!

title: Charming, historic restaurant for breakfast or lunch
text:
We were on our first visit to Arcadia and this little place and the warm welcome we received. It was early for lunch, but our waitress assured us we could order lunch sandwiches if we chose. And we did--ham and cheese with fries, and for me, a tuna melt with a side green salad. There are old-fashioned side boards or buffets, cut glass items and plenty of china tea pots on display along with old-time ladies and men's hats.
There was one other diner there and our table was far away from hers so we felt very comfortable. And since they make their own scones and baklava, we bought some to have at home.
All in all, a pleasant treat!

title: Secluded but very accessible preserve
text: This preserve is on the outskirts of Boothbay Harbor and is mostly flat and therefore, easy walking and accessible for wheelchairs. There are several trails and they go through wooded areas as well as meadows and with views of the small lake with cattails and blue flowers. There is a short bridge to cross. Although the literature cites it as very popular with folks, we were the only ones there the day we went.

title: Wonderful selection of seafood and beef plus much more!
text: Since last year, Pinkham’s has expanded their inventory of canned and dry goods to include a wide variety of condiments and sauces and pasta including some Indian jarred sauces. The fish and seafood selection is extensive and very fresh! And you can get some top cut steaks. We also like their prepared cole slaw. Staff are generally very helpful; a few are a bit on the indifferent side and could be a bit warmer and appreciative of the business.

title: Generous lobster rolls!
text: We ordered lobster rolls and a salad as takeout and were very pleased. The lobster was fresh and plentiful, the bun was appropriately toasted and buttered. And since it was before the August crowd, ordering and wait time were very reasonable.

title: Great takeout experience!
text:
We ordered one of the signature pizzas with arugula, a Caesar salad, and an order of the chicken Parmesan. Everything was very tasty! We called and ordered an early pick-up time and so the order was ready when we arrived.

This is a great affiliate of Ports of Italy!

title: Love this shop!
text: The shop is better than ever! Lots of books and activities for kids, pretty cloth napkins, jewelry (specially earrings), and other temptations. They used to carry a wonderful selection of paper cocktail napkins and I was sorry they stop stocking them.
place: Coastal Maine Botanical Gardens Gift Shop

title: Great garden worth a detour!
text: Covid-19 has made some changes necessary to the garden, the first being you must reserve an entry time beforehand, even if you are a member. And some of the spaces that are most appealing to younger children like the playhouse and the story barn are closed. But the flowers are lovely as always and there are woodlands and other areas to explore. This remains one of my favorite area attractions!

title: Good food, but slow service
text: This is an attractive small place along Tamiami Trail and just right for lunch. It's a popular place and filled up quickly the day we were there. Menu has a wide variety of salads and sandwiches as well as entree portions. I enjoyed their arugula salad with cherry tomatoes, hard boiled egg, and the addition of some chicken. As others have written, service is very slow so best to plan not to have a quick lunch.

title: Rustic decor for fresh fish!
text: A friend and I had lunch here and very much enjoyed with good selection of fresh fish on the menu. She opted for the ahi tuna appetizer (really more of a salad) and I ordered the mahi mahi sandwich grilled with a side of cole slaw. Indoor seating is wooden tables with exposed beams and some outside seating, mostly high tables or bar seating. Very popular place, good service and you can even buy fish to take home from their large case. We arrived before noon and didn't have to wait!

title: Great little Italian restaurant!
text: A young couple from Italy run this restaurant and they pour their heart and soul into providing tasty food and a nice ambiance. He's the chef and she'f front of house. Their chicken or salmon dishes are excellent and the ravioli and lasagna also very tasty! It's small so best to reserve a table ahead.

title: Best ice cream around!
text: This family run ice cream shop and cafe has an amazing variety of ice cream flavors, some made without sugar. Stop in to take home a pint or indulge in a cone or dish. I like their peppermint as well as mint chocolate chip and butter pecan.

title: Lovely barrier island!
text: Longboat Key has some wonderful restaurants and lots of places to stay plus some attractive beaches. Some areas are private, but it's worth visiting for dining and just the overall scenery.

title: Top notch dining--sophisticated and excellent!
text: We brought visiting friends here for dinner and were most pleased with everything we ordered. Both the swordfish and the red snapper were superb and the ribs were also pronounced excellent. Our server was pleasant, helpful in guiding our choices, and had a sense of humor. The place is popular and it was noisy, but we enjoyed ourselves nevertheless.

title: Perfectly located, comfortable hotel
text: The DeSoto is centrally located in the historic district between Chippewa Square and Madison Square within easy walking distance of both the river and Forsyth Park. The lobby is open and spacious and very contemporary with art by SCAD students. Our room was comfortable with a great view of the river skyline. And the hotel staff were most accommodating and took care of all our requests from extra blankets to assistance with restaurant bookings. I would single out Avi in the dining room, Unique at the front desk and also the staff in Edgar's Provision. They all made our stay most enjoyable. And the interns working at breakfast were pleasant and helpful and we even got good black tea (not Early Grey!)

title: Noisy dining room, but food better than we expected!
text: This is a vey popular place and the service is friendly, but a bit brisk. We were pleased that the maitre d’ came over to our table to ask how everything was and to say that he’d be happy to take care of anything we needed. Lots of selections on the menu, but we have smaller appetites so all ordered an appetizer and a salad and had plenty to eat. The shrimp, crab, sausage spring roll was delectable (3 of them on the plate) and the BLT salad a treat with fried green tomatoes, good bacon and all on a small bed of lettuce with a tasty buttermilk dressing. The appetizer shrimp and grits were a hit with another fo our friends while he didn’t love their approach to chicken pot pie. Would have been even more enjoyable in a quieter space.

title: Much to see along this active river port!
text: River Street has been nicely renovated into a nice promenade with shops and restaurants on one side and monuments and the occasional statue on the other plus a string of billboards detailing Savannah’s history and its relationship to this river. We watched the ferry boat make the crossing to the convention center and then were awed by an up close view of a container ship being guided into port. Much to see. Many of the restaurants are old ones, and some look overly touristy, but the river views are worth coming down to this part of the city.

title: Inviting cafe for some java!
text: Cozy welcoming spot for coffee, of course, but also for homemade pastries and some lunch fare. We stopped in for a cappuccino and a chocolate croissant and both were delicious. On the way out, I had a lovely I chat with Laurie, the owner who stopped to ask me where I was from. She was delightful and meeting her just added to the richness of the experience.

title: Charming and cozy ambience paired with tasty lunch fare!
text: Lunch in this charming library-like cafe with stained glass touches and an impressive chandelier was delicious! Great service from our SCAD student waiter (SCAD owns the building) and some tasty lighter fare. Several of us enjoyed the shrimp salad on Bibb lettuce while others sampled an entree salad and the smoked salmon club sandwich. The perfect place for a relaxed meal.

title: Stunning architecture and some intriguing exhibits!
text: A couple of the current exhibits are very different and while we wondered at first if they would appeal to us, we were pleasantly surprised. “Machines of Futility” included the quirky and fun robotic voice activated machine. You said something into a tube and then your words were spelled across a screen and dumped below. The interactive exhibit, in its last week, is definitely a must and part of a focus on science and nature. We especially liked putting on the virtual reality goggles and being transported to the coral reef tank at the California Academy of Sciences. Highly recommend visiting!

title: Mixed beginning resulted in a most satisfactory experience!
text: The hotel dining room is closed on Mondays so we resorted to Proof and initially were not happy about the lack of good table seating. Nonetheless, we started at some lounge chairs for drinks and some very tasty potato chips with a truffled chipotle dip and then moved to a low table with stools (better than the other seating for eating, but still backless). The fish tacos were excellent as were the chicken wings and the very large Cobb salad. Our waitress was very accommodating and we ended up enjoying the overall experience!

title: Popular restaurant with good food, but felt a bit processed
text: Vic’s is a popular restaurant for Southern cooking. The dining rooms are large and noisy with mostly hard surfaces. My crab cakes, virtually all crab, were excellent! The entree came with a romaine salad, a wedge with a choice of dressing, a few cherry tomatoes and cucumber slices as well as two large croutons. A friend ordered the meatloaf, a gargantuan slice, which he had enjoyed also on a previous visit. I found the service efficient, but a bit too brisk as our waiter snatched some plates before everyone had finished and also was less than fair in how he poured our wine. Overall the food surpassed the service.

title: Lovely, charming walkable area!
text: Savannah’s Historic District is quiet, so very pedestrian friendly, and loaded with history. The small squares are lovely with statues and monuments and checking them out is an easy way to learn a lot of history from colonial times through the Civil War. All have benches and the live oaks dripping with Spanish moss provide shade if needed. Easy to spend a lot of time here just wandering and reading the plaques.

title: Innovative Southern cuisine in an elegant setting!
text: Lunch in this elegant space was a treat! Their pimento cheese with homemade benne crackers delicious and the ham and biscuit starter a very generous amount of ham. A couple of us enjoyed the cobra with sour grits and collard chow chow while our compatriots sampled the pastrami tongue sandwich and the hot fried chicken. Excellent and long wine list and we indulged in a French Chablis.

title: Breakfast classics!
text: A very popular diner-like place for breakfast!We met friends there and while we ate more lightly, he tucked into eggs and toast and all the trimmings. Seating is a mix of booths and tables.

title: Great shopping for the ladies, dining for all!
text: We spent several hours here strolling the circle and wandering in and out of shops. Lots of clothing shops, jewelry stores, tee shirt places, and many restaurants. My spouse noted that the stores appealing to men are few and that it’s great for the women as demonstrated by the fact that my sister and I bought earrings and a top. Restaurant choices are great—everything from Cuban to seafood and fish to sandwiches and from casual to classier like Shore. Now that there is a parking garage, we will get there more often!!

title: Outstanding addition to the local art scene!
text: We made our inaugural visit to this new art museum with visiting family and were all very impressed! The gallery spaces are lovely, the color stripes and confetti leading up from the lobby to the two floors of exhibits eye catching and fun. The “Color Theory” exhibit brings together works of sculpture and painting, etc. by disparate artists and is both intriguing and amusing. And the Vik Muniz retrospective is amazing for the range of types of art and materials he used—everything from paper cutouts for collages to toy soldiers, sugar, chocolate syrup and peanut butter and jam which formed the images he then photographed to preserve as a completed piece. Worth visiting again and again since the exhibits will change!

title: Elegant dining in a popular place!
text: Another very popular restaurant whose popularity is well deserved. We were there on a Saturday night early and the dining room was already pretty full. Service is professional albeit a bit rushed (we were not going to a performance afterwards). I enjoyed my salad followed by salmon on with salsa on a bed of risotto with green beans. Dining room is white tablecloth attractive.

title: Tasty lunch with a crowd!
text: Very popular lunch spot on the circle! Get there early if you don’t want to wait in line. Large dining room and a menu with lots of choices of food with a Cuban flair. Tables are very close together so not the place for a romantic tete-a-tete. We ordered the Cubano sandwich, a mahi mahi sandwich with melted cheese and fried onions that was scrumptious, the tomato tart, and some salads. Noise level is high. Service was reasonable.

title: Sophisticated fare in Bradenton!
text: This is a great addition to the local dining scene! There's a bar area, high tables for tall millennials and regular table seating in a quieter area. The menu is imaginative and creative with options from small bites (think tapas) to appetizers and entrees. And a good selection of wines by the bottle and some by the glass. We opted for the croquettes, the tournedos with foie gras (sublime!) and some Calabrian chili shrimp plus the really fun and delicious truffled popcorn. We arrived when they opened at 5:00 and before 5:30, the dining room was full! Not sure they take reservations so be plan accordingly. Definitely a restaurant this foodie will quickly return to as I think it's one of the best in the greater Bradenton-Sarasota area!

title: Great place for breakfast at LGA!
text: We had breakfast here before our flight and I had one of the best omelets ever! I chose build your own and with spinach, cheese and bacon, it was light and perfect. Ordering is on an iPad screen, but wait staff are around to assist if needed and service was quick.

title: Old world decor and charm!
text: An old world place with gracious service and delicious food. We had lunch here as a treat. Saltimbocca and the spinach filled manicotti were wonderful!

title: Worth visiting in its expanded quarters!
text: We were here briefly on a crowded pre-holiday visit and need to return. But it’s still a great museum and there is more gallery space and more to see! Our membership cards didn’t match the online expiration date. We were pleased that it all it took was a quick visit to the membership counter to get the future expiration date verified and to walk away with new revised cards. Super!

title: Comfortable theater showing 1st run and unusual films
text: Cine 123 is conveniently located near Bloomindale’s on the Upper East Side. The seats are comfortable and the theaters are almost intimate. Limited concessions, but very good early bird (before noon) admission of $10 a person. My favorite cinema in this neighborhood!

title: Lively vibe and tasty Italian fare!
text: This lively Italian restaurant is family friendly with a wide variety of menu choices. Everything from pizzas and cheese and meat platters to salads and tasty pasta dishes. Service was brisk to almost rushed, but not quite. The welcome was friendly and my spouse and I particularly enjoyed the salad with walnuts and Gorgonzola and his ravioli with guanciale. We also tried the penne with cubes of fresh tuna and black olives in a tomato sauce. Portions are large so sharing a salad is a good idea. Definitely a place to put on our return list!

title: Great exhibits in this small gem!
text: One might not realize that this private club dedicated to books and book publishing opens its exhibits to the public. And for no charge whatsoever. We visited expressly to see the “500 Years of Works by Women” and it was well worth it. Consisting of selections from a massive collection of printed works from the 16th century onward, it is drawn from the Baskin collection at Duke University. There are lovely examples of printing and binding by women as well as numerous books written by women. This exhibit is on into early February and there was a smaller exhibit on the upper floor as well.

title: Very good food; overlook the brusque service
text: We are always pleased with the food here, but do occasionally mind the brusqueness of some of the wait staff. There’s a peremptory quality to it and you can feel almost attacked as soon as you are seated. Make up your mind quickly about what you’d like to drink, then you can peruse the menu in a more relaxed manner. That said, our waiter this time was very good and we enjoyed two veal dishes plus a side order of the gnocchi with Gorgonzola cream sauce. The latter were good, but would have been even better with even more of the cheese. A popular place that works to turn their tables efficiently so reservations are highly recommended.

title: One of our favorite UES restaurants for everyday dining!
text: A cozy restaurant with consistently good service and food. We like the 3-course prix-fixe which has a nice selection of choices. The roast chicken is always good as is the salmon with green beans and white beans. And on the regular menu, there’s also a tasty chicken paillard with greens and always a soup du jour. The red pepper soup the other night was especially tasty!

title: One of the friendliest diners around!
text: We love the warm welcome given as we enter! Great service all around and one of the best iterations of a grilled bacon and cheese. The tuna melt on an English muffin is quite good also.

title: Zippy food in a lively space!
text: This tapas place is popular, especially with the younger crowd. We dined here on a Friday night and found the tapas we ordered delicious! The shrimps in olive oil and garlic, the patatas brava, and the citrus salad (loved the combo of grapefruit, manchego and fennel) were all tasty. Note that all the seating is at high tables (a challenge for us shorties) and there is loud music. We were right under a speaker.

title: Nicely curated selection of wines!
text: Great place to lift a glass of wine before dinner or almost anytime! Lots of wines by the glass from which to choose and we enjoyed several different ones along with conversation with the hotel owner.

title: Great tour of this former hotel!
text: This hour-long tour is led by a current student and the young woman who gave our tour was knowledgeable and fun. Formerly the Ponce de Leon Hotel, this is a very grand building with Tiffany glass and luxurious furnishings throughout. Worth the modest admission charge!

title: Mixed bag on this main drag
text: Some of St. George Street is very nice, but there are a lot of tacky tourist shops and oodles of bars and pubs that detract a bit from the wonderfully historic architecture. Lots of history here, but you have to work and walk a bit to discover it. The square right off St. George Street was in full Christmas mode with four live Christmas trees each decorated differently, Christmas lights, a sleigh, a snowman and even a penguin. Walk it, but do realize that there are many other intriguing sights around this district!

title: Cozy pub for lunch!
text: We were the only diners at lunch time and wondered how the food would be. But, we were pleased that both the food and the service were very good. The crab cakes with accompaniment were tasty and the chicken pesto burrito was excellent. And our food came very quickly, along with a beer or two!

title: Wide range of rooms usually above retail stores
text: The inn owns six buildings (mix of old and new) around the historic district and some of the rooms are slightly funky. We were in one of the older buildings with a balcony and a king size bed. Right outside was a row of air conditioners, but because we weren’t there in the summer, the room was quiet. Bed was very comfortable. Bathroom had sink in ante area. Hotel staff were exceptionally welcoming and friendly and the breakfast that came with the room was a mini buffet of pastry, fruit, a cheese, ham and salami and granola. Very nice. For future stays, the staff advised us to look at the photos of the rooms online before booking.

title: Wonderfully fresh fish and great flavors!
text: This casual place has wood tables and an informal vibe. We loved the trio of dips (pico de gallo, guacamole and pimento fondue) with chips to start. Our guys sampled the delicious Minorcan seafood chowder. The flounder on risotto was different and exceptionally wonderful. Great service and a fun place to dine.

title: Lovely Christmas tree!
text: A most attractive square which adds to the charm of this small downtown shopping area. Dominating it this time of year was a lovely large Christmas tree.

title: The place to see and be seen for lunch in Ocala!
text: I think this may be part of a chain (there’s a Harry’s in St. Augustine), but it was very good and the service lightning quick. We told our waitress we were on a tight timeline and she delivered our food super fast. The salmon salad was tasty, if a bit overdressed and our companions all liked what they ordered as well. Booth and table seating in a pleasant space.

title: Small gem of a museum!
text: Just outside the small city of Ocala in north central Florida, the Appleton is a very attractive modern building. Go now if you like Christmas displays as this one is amazing and very extensive. Also, the current traveling exhibit on Impressionism in the Americas is superb! Created by the Reading Museum in Pennsylvania, it will travel on from here.
